The chamber attendants here are always unfailingly courteous. This has been just such a great workplace. Everybody just makes it tick in such a nice and friendly and courteous fashion.

I would like to finish by firstly thanking my parents for the opportunity they gave me as a child growing up. I'm not your typical Liberal-background politician. My parents are working class. My mum was a full-time mum. My dad was a factory worker. He got sick; he ended up on a disability pension. They had four kids by the time they were 28. It wasn't plain sailing, but they bent over backwards to give me the best possible opportunity, and for that I will forever be grateful.

I would like to finish by saying a very sincere thank you to Hayley. Hayley is an outstanding woman. She's an amazing individual. She's obviously my life's partner and best friend. She's an amazing mother to our beautiful children, Isabelle and Charlotte, but she's an outstanding professional woman with a distinguished career in her own right. She was the President of the Law Society in WA at age 35. I'm so proud of what Hayley has achieved now working at the bar in Perth and to observe the respect in which she's held by her colleagues and her peers in that profession. Hayley had to build her career throughout that entire period while I was mostly away. During the seven years as finance minister, I was essentially over east every week from the middle of January to the middle of December—every week. We have two kids. Hayley had her own career. I was over here. So she has carried a very substantial burden for me being able to pursue this opportunity to do this job, and I will forever be grateful for that. Thank you very much, Hayley.

So, colleagues, this is my last contribution from this chair in this chamber. There is probably more that I could or should have said, but I think the hour is advancing. I give you this commitment: after today, I won't be back!

Senator WONG (South Australia—Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (12:02): I rise on this, the valedictory of my friend and colleague Mathias Cormann, and I wish to say a few words personally but also on behalf of the Labor Party as he leaves this chamber. When Mathias announced his intention to resign, I put out a statement in which I said he was:
… a formidable opponent & a trusted counterpart: a parliamentarian of the old school.

So I'm going to go through those briefly. First, we'll start with 'formidable opponent'. When I was a minister—I'm not from WA, so I didn't engage with him on the plane et cetera—the first thing I remember about Mathias—I was kind of engaged in climate policy, which was not the easiest ministerial job to start with—was this bloke with a German accent who kept asking me questions and then started following me around at estimates, not in a stalking sense but in turning up to estimates. I thought, 'Who is this bloke?' Anyway, we did have quite a lot of interchanges at estimates. He subsequently said to me, when he became a minister and he wasn't answering questions, that he'd learnt a lot about how not to really answer the questions from me when I was a minister, but I think that is a vicious, vicious calumny—definitely untrue!

Our combat has been pretty hard at times. I think it's generally not been personal or churlish. He did once try calling me 'Australia's worst finance minister'. I pointed out to him that my net debt was lower, my gross debt was lower and my tax-to-GDP ratio was lower, and he didn't keep going with it, although he keeps going occasionally with the same sort of exaggerated position that the coalition had to put in place to justify the 2014 budget. But, notwithstanding the results of this budget, I'm not going to return the favour of the moniker. I don't think that's a practice we should continue.

I didn't know Mathias well when we were in government and he was in opposition, but I do remember one rather untoward event at estimates where I realised he must be a reasonably decent man. I don't wish to embarrass the particular other senator, but I got meowed at in estimates, and it got quite a bit of media. The bloke subsequently apologised, and we all moved on. But I remember Mathias sitting there, almost with his hand in his mouth, not saying anything. I thought, 'Well, maybe this bloke is actually decent.'

I described him as a trusted counterpart. He is. He's a decent man and he's an honourable man. I'm sure he would be the first to say he's made mistakes at times. But I don't think, between us, we have ever breached a confidence. We have always sought to honour our commitments to each other. I have valued that greatly. There are not many people about whom you can say that in politics. It has been something I have valued greatly.

I also described him as a parliamentarian of the old school. I just want to talk briefly about what I meant when I said that. The first—and we saw it again today in his contribution, although I noticed he didn't acknowledge the Social Democratic Party of Germany, our sister party, in his contribution about the wall, but leaving that aside—is that he has a belief in democracy. A belief in democracy is more than just words; it's a respect for institutions. It demands a respect for norms and conventions, a respect for this parliament. Mathias brings that to his job. Sometimes I think, as I said yesterday, that he should have answered more questions, but he does understand that, as much as our Constitution and our history, our democracy depends on what we do here and how we behave here.

I think one thing we share is a belief in the importance of containing conflict. Now, that might sound to those opposite a little odd, coming from Penny Wong, but it's actually so important. Politics is, as some have said, war by other means. It's what we do to resolve conflict. We don't have revolutions, we don't get out guns, we don't become vigilantes. We fight here. There must be limits, there must be containment, because conflict without any limit risks destroying too much. It risks damaging the polity, the people, the community, the institution, too much. That is one thing I think Mathias and I have shared—an understanding of what we wanted to fight about and what we wanted to make sure we didn't fight about. Some of those limits are set by our democratic traditions, by our democratic system, by norms and conventions. Some of them should be set by decency—things like the limitations around personal attacks and an understanding that disengagement is sometimes required and, on some issues, that we shouldn't be partisan.

There are many examples I could give of times where, regardless of our very different views on some issues, we would have conversations which were about: 'We need to make sure there's bipartisanship on this. We need to make sure there's limited conflict on this.' One of them that I remember—because it meant a lot to me, because of my history and my experience of racism when I was young—was after the Fraser Anning comments. People might recall we had a bipartisan motion. I remember ringing Mathias from out the back, next to the kids' trampoline, and I said: 'It would be really good if we could move this motion together. It would say something. There's a lot of conflict, and people can do a lot of politics about it, but people need to hear a defence of multiculturalism and the assertion of inclusion from us both.' It's not the only thing we've worked on together. Some of the things I'm honour-bound to keep between us! But it was important. You heard Senator Cormann start today with a discussion about us both having a migrant background—him much later in life, obviously. I think that has informed some of what we understand to be outside of the zone of desirable conflict in a democracy.

I will miss our contest. I'll miss our catch-ups and the very good red wine. I'll miss our friendship—although I, too, hope we maintain it beyond this. I'll miss sharing photos and stories of our children across the table during question time. I want to acknowledge your contribution to the nation and to the parliament. I wish more of it had been in opposition! I want to thank Hayley for her contribution to the nation, and I want to say: I reckon he's been pretty lucky and he's got a lot better with your influence. To Isabelle and Charlotte: it's wonderful you get to have your father back, in a different way. So, Mathias, I wish you well, personally, for all that lies beyond, and I thank you for your friendship and for your contribution.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Minister for Employment, Skills, Small and Family Business) (12:11): I, too, rise this afternoon, with both enormous respect and a touch of sadness, to pay tribute to my friend and colleague Senator the Hon. Mathias Cormann. More than 12 years ago, when I entered this place, I took up my place beside you as a fellow senator for the great state of Western Australia. Now I stand here today contributing to your valedictory, and I can genuinely say that, over the years in this place, you have been a true friend. I thank you for both your friendship and your steadfast representation of the values that you and I hold so dear.

Mathias, in your more than 13 years in this place, you have left a mark that few others will ever emulate. Your achievements in this place and your service to our nation's wellbeing will have an impact for decades to come. Your legacy will be enduring. Colleagues, in Mathias's maiden speech in 2007, he said this:

… this is a country where, if you put your shoulder to the wheel, work hard, embrace the people and values and become an integral part of the community—in short, if you have a go—there is no limit to what you can achieve in your chosen field of endeavour. We all come to this place with a commitment to make a positive difference. Other than our energy and our enthusiasm, we bring to the table our background, our experiences and our values.

Mathias, yours is, without a doubt, a great Australian story and one that should inspire anyone, from any background, who wants to succeed. You came here as an immigrant in your 20s and you embraced your new home. You've made a valuable contribution to our country through an incredible amount of hard work, 25 hours a day, eight days a week. That's just how you work. But it is this commitment and determination—and I think my colleagues will agree, no matter how frustrating it is for the rest of us when we receive a text from you at midnight on a Sunday and you expect a timely response!—that has seen you succeed in everything you do.

Over the last few months, as our nation has faced the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic, you as the Minister for Finance, as part of the team, knew what needed to be done to provide the support to drive the economic recovery. As the Prime Minister himself has stated, your work as our finance minister for seven years saw our nation enter COVID-19 in a far stronger position than it otherwise would have been. It therefore allowed us to bring forward initiatives such as the JobKeeper payment, the JobKeeper supplement, the 'supporting apprentices and trainees' initiative and the many, many other initiatives which will help our economic recovery.

For me, it is a personally bittersweet moment that you are leaving this place. I am so pleased for your new opportunity as Australia's candidate for Secretary-General of the OECD. You will make, if elected, an incredibly valuable contribution to promoting not only growth but also opportunity across the globe. As fellow Western Australian Liberal senators, we have been a united team since that meeting back in 2006. It was 7 am and we met at the then famous Bar One on St Georges Terrace in Perth for breakfast and, as Mathias liked to call it, 'a chat'. That chat, though, ultimately changed the course of both our lives, and here we are in 2020. I can honestly say that supporting you in your preselection was one of the best decisions I've ever made, and we've had each other's back ever since. In fact, colleagues, as many of you will know, every year since I was elected Mathias and I have held the Cormann-Cash annual state council Christmas function. This year we'll hold our 13th and final function, and boy will it be a big night!

Mathias, your achievements in this place are extensive. You have been an effective senator, passionately representing the interests of our great state. You may not have been born in Western Australia but you are, without a doubt, a sandgroper through and through. It was your leadership of our WA team and your constant advocacy that ensured Western Australia did get a fair deal, and now gets a fair deal when it comes to GST distribution. All of the WA team, many of whom have joined us here today, were proud to stand and fight with you. For many years to come this is something that our great state will not forget, and it will continue to have a positive impact in Western Australia.

In your leadership roles, you have well and truly mastered this place—as Senator Wong herself acknowledged—whether it was working behind the scenes with colleagues within the government or reaching out and working with the opposition, the crossbench and the Australian Greens. When it comes to your role as finance minister, there is no question that you have consistently followed the principles you laid out in your maiden speech: free enterprise, individual freedom, personal responsibility, reward for effort, low taxation, less regulation and incentives for people to stretch themselves and to reach their full potential. The reason you are so successful is your incredible work ethic and the fact that—again, as Senator Wong, herself articulated—you treat all senators, regardless of their political affiliation, with respect.

In your maiden speech to this place you also said, 'Politics at its best is a noble profession. It is a noble pursuit.' In your case, history will record that you have carried yourself with great nobility. As we all know, it is often said that one of the greatest achievements in politics is to leave at a time of your choosing and on your own terms, and, my friend, you are doing exactly that. You leave this place with an outstanding record of service and achievement to undertake a new opportunity to serve both our nation and the world.

Mathias, we will all miss your contribution in this place, and I will certainly miss you as a colleague and a friend. I wish you all the best in your next chapter but in particular, as Senator Wong said, with Hayley, Charlotte and Isabelle. I conclude by saying: farewell, good and faithful servant of Western Australia and, indeed, Australia generally. Mathias, my friend, thank you.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (12:18): I rise as Leader of The Nationals in the Senate and join everybody here. The fact that it's a valedictory and we've still got the stands packed I think is a testament to the man whose valedictory we're participating in today.

You are so patriotic, Mathias, for your adopted nation. You're a senator's senator, and we want to make sure there are more of those around. Your contribution to the parliament, to the coalition and to our nation has been significant, and I'm looking forward to it continuing in another role.

You've been Leader of the Government in the Senate since 2017, and it was my great honour, as Deputy Leader of the Nationals, to sit in that leadership group heading into the 2019 election and, again, to work with you post the election as the Leader of the Nationals. I think it's your integrity, your trust and your value system—and your sense of humour, at times, and your patience, too—that really meant that we could get the results that we needed to.

Former Nationals leaders Warren Truss and Barnaby Joyce and the current DPM, Michael McCormack, have all spoken highly about working with you in their former and current roles, as has Nigel Scullion, another Senate leader and Nashie you've worked with. I spoke to Warren Truss, the former Deputy Prime Minister, earlier today, and he was unequivocal: he believes you're the most outstanding finance minister we've seen. It's your attention to detail, the fact that you're across your brief and that you approach negotiations rationally, calmly and reasonably. 'You don't always win, with Mathias,' he said, 'but you know you've had a fair hearing.' So thank you for the work that you do in that way.

Whether negotiating the fuel excise or championing our live export and mining sectors, the National Party and Senator Cormann saw eye to eye on many, many issues. I think it's his rock-solid commitment as a true coalitionist—you can't say that about everybody in the Liberal Party, but Mathias Cormann is a true coalitionist, because he understands that together the Liberal Party and the National Party provide strong, stable government for our nation, and that's the best outcome in the national interest. The mining sector that you championed for WA wasn't just for WA, and the Nationals want to thank you for your attention to that.

It's sage advice to always pay attention to the smartest guy in the room. He can be your friend and supporter—or not! I think it's always best to do that, and you always display a commitment to try to be the former. You have an unwavering commitment to bettering the lives of all Australians, and I think you spoke earlier about your upbringing and what role that played in the value system and world view you brought to this place. I think we're all the richer for hearing that here. You have been a rock-like figure for the coalition ever since you came to parliament and we're going to miss you severely.

We mentioned estimates briefly; what I love about watching Mathias in estimates—and, again, it's like being schooled—is that he has an army of public servants, every seat behind him is taken up, and Rosemary is there; she has all the folders, but he takes every question. And he can answer them; he's across the detail, and that is exactly how this process is meant to work. It's an incredible privilege to watch you on FPA.

We are from generation X, and I do want to share that in some of those late-night sittings we had some good tunes with former Senator Fifield, Cashie and Parry. It was all good fun, but I think, Mathias, that what you have brought here has provided, in my experience, some of the great moments of this chamber, and Senator Wong mentioned one earlier. There is the ability of both of you to come together in really key and significant moments, such as on the issue of racism. That was one of the most powerful moments that I think this chamber has ever seen and it was a great privilege to be able to sit here and see both of you. I'm proud of our nation for sending you both and then proud of you both as individuals for giving us, as senators, that moment in our nation. Yes, you have shown us what this chamber is capable of through that. I think, Mathias, that your commitment to the traditions and values of this chamber is as a senator's senator and that you have a partner in the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate who has helped you to fulfil that.
I'm nearly finished, but I'm just going to recite a poem which I think may describe Mathias's approach to politics.
Panic bells, it's red alert
There's something here from somewhere else
The war machine springs to life
Opens up one eager eye
Focusing it on the sky
Where ninety-nine red balloons go by
Ninety-nine decision street
Ninety-nine ministers meet
To worry, worry, super scurry—
It sounds like budget prep!—
Call the troops out in a hurry
That's the sell!—
This is what we've waited for
This is it, boys, this is war
The president is on the line
As ninety-nine red balloons go by

He is a coalitionist to the core, and that requires true respect and mutual appreciation that there are two independent parties here. Mathias, that is the key to your success in that role. I look forward to working with Birmo to that end.

It is also your pragmatic and rational approach to policy decisions. When you stood as a fresh-faced newcomer in August 2007 and made your first speech you thanked then President Ferguson, from South Australia, for his advice and wisdom. I'll lift a few lines from that young Western Australian senator: 'Thank you for the advice and wisdom you have shared with me in the time we've sat in this chamber. I have very much appreciated the generosity towards me as a new senator'—and me as a leader. In more recent times I have been sincerely grateful to have had the privilege to work alongside you. I've always admired your passion and commitment to our Liberal and National parties coalition. I respect your directness in standing up for what you believe in and bringing those values here as a conviction politician.
All the best—and I'm not going to try German—and bonne chance for the next chapter.

Senator WATERS (Queensland—Leader of the Australian Greens in the Senate) (12:26): I rise on behalf of the Australian Greens to acknowledge Senator Cormann and his work and enormous contribution to this place over many years. Having only recently stepped into the role of Leader of the Greens in the Senate—and in a year when we have all been here less than we otherwise would have—I have not had the opportunity to engage with you closely.

Our politics are poles apart, but across the political spectrum you're seen as a no-nonsense straight talker who is extremely bright, across their brief and always working very hard. You're also praised for being a strong negotiator, but sometimes we don't like the outcomes that you negotiate. Our chamber will certainly miss someone so erudite that they can respond in multiple languages at the drop of a hat, as you did yesterday. I must say that I won't miss you rejecting the premise of my questions, but I do respect your conviction and your work ethic.

I have been in touch with former Greens leader and senator Richard Di Natale, who asked me to pass on some sentiments from him. Richard said that, despite having very different political philosophies, you have his respect and his trust. He wishes you the very best in your next phase of life and assures you that you won't regret it.

As a senator and minister from Perth, with all the travel that that entails I'm sure that you'll enjoy some extra time with your family. It is very well earned. Your words about your family were very touching. We wish you all the very best.

Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (12:27): In adding to the many fine words said about our friend and colleague Senator Mathias Cormann, I want to focus on just a few brief points. Mathias, you leave here with a number of attributes that very few people carry in this place at the very end of their time of service. You leave with respect and admiration, as we are hearing from friend and foe alike in the political context. That is testament to the way in which you have engaged, as we have heard from so many.

You leave also with achievement and legacy. You have not just served time in this place; you have achieved outcomes. For those outcomes you can leave with a sense of pride. Your family can have pride that the sacrifice has been worthy. Our government, our side of politics, and the nation should give thanks for what you have achieved in that time.

You have also demonstrated drive to the final moment of your service in this chamber. You are not one who has put his feet up towards the end. As anyone who has been in receipt of text messages this week knows and anyone who was involved in the preparation of the budget this week knows, you have been there driving relentlessly, and ruthlessly where necessary, right through.

We arrived in this chamber just a few weeks apart, as senators filling casual vacancies in the final few months of the Howard government. We have lived many ups and downs during that time. It is wonderful to stand here at a high point for our government but a most challenging point for the nation as you move into the next phase of your life.

I think back to our journey through the days in opposition when, yes, there were times when we would tag-team speaking along with a number of others, much to Senator Wong and others' consternation, for sometimes many hours on end. We would rail against the ruthless exercise of the guillotine by Senator Wong and other Labor ministers at the time. But, as Senator Cormann reflected, we learnt a few lessons along the way about when and how to do so. We moved into government, you straight into the cabinet as the finance minister for the whole duration of our time in government. That is a remarkable achievement by you and will be deeply felt by the government in terms of you leaving that role and that loss of continuity.

I, in many roles, have fronted up to the ERC to be bounced out with a Mathias Cormann 'no, go back and sharpen up the pencil for something that comes at lower cost'. Again, just as we learnt some tactics from Senator Wong in opposition, colleagues, hopefully, I've learnt some tactics from Senator Cormann to take into those ERC conversations.
Senator Cormann: I hope so too!

Senator BIRMINGHAM: Rosemary, I know you hope that I have too! In a leadership context, you have managed not only to negotiate the coalition, each of our parties with our points of difference at times, and to show respect to those points of difference but also, hopefully, to bring us to points of unity. It is on that front that I hope we can all continue to work together in the same vein. Both you and Senator Wong have spoken some fine words about how this chamber—this parliament, this place—best works. It's not to say that we aren't a robust democracy; we must be a robust democracy—that is absolutely how it best work—but it is also the case that we should all be mindful of the way in which we engage in that robust activity. I think you have both brought out the best in the debate today in doing so.

I add my thanks to Hayley and my best wishes to Hayley, Charlotte and Isabelle in terms of the future ahead. I, of course, am not hoping that they have quite as much of your time and your freedom as some have reflected, because I hope from the perspective of the portfolio that I currently hold that we enjoy the success of your candidacy for the Secretary-General of the OECD and that that leads to a new but equally busy life. It will be a different life, but one where you will make different contributions while still bringing, though, the same drive and values that help not just our country and our economy but countries and economies across the globe to succeed in the future. You're the right man for that job. You've been the right man for the jobs in which you have served in this place and, for that, we thank you.

Senator PATRICK (South Australia) (12:32): Senator Cormann, I will be one of the many who are very sad to see you go. I think you're a huge loss to the government. You played the role not just of Leader of the Government in the Senate and finance minister but also of the crossbench whisperer. It's from that perspective I'm going to talk briefly about my experiences with you. My experience with you started actually not as a senator but as an adviser to Nick Xenophon. I was involved in a negotiation on paragraph 4.7 of the Commonwealth Procurement Rules. When I first walked into your office, even as a staffer, you were very respectful of me and we've heard that word being used a lot throughout the speeches today. On my first day as a senator I thought, 'I'm going to take this bloke on.' For the final supplementary question to my first question without notice, I said:
Minister, you are the crossbench whisperer: the deal maker. What effect do you think this breach of agreement with NXT will have on future crossbench negotiations?

You can see how he's responding there, and I will eventually come back to that, but that's the point at which I worked out what Mathias's greatest weakness was but also his greatest strength, and that was he cares about relationships. In my view that has been his success in this place, because he has maintained relationships with everyone.

In your role as the crossbench whisperer, we haven't always agreed. There have been times when you've annoyed me, there have been times when I've annoyed you, and there have been times when I've really annoyed you. But it's fair to say that always, always, you were professional. We've always had a very professional relationship.

One of the things that have impressed me most about you—and I'm a crossbencher who has to deal with lots and lots of bits of legislation as well as all of the other tasks—is that you are always across your brief. You are very impressive in that regard. When we negotiate, you've always been respectful. Things that were done in confidence were always held confidential, even at the point of disagreeing about things. I could always trust you, and I could always trust you in delivering. You were always available. Senator Cash talked about a 12-midnight text. I remember one time having a meeting with Senator Cormann in Melbourne—actually, it was a dinner meeting. We had a dinner meeting to resolve an issue to do with shipbuilding, and I won't say much more than this; in 30 years time maybe someone will write about it. We had a dinner. I went back to my cheap hotel—he was staying in a more expensive hotel—and at 4 am I woke up and thought, 'Maybe I've got a solution to this.' I sent him a text saying, 'Are you awake?' and he came back—of course he was awake. I said, 'If you can organise coffee in your hotel, I'll be there at 5 am,' and we met and resolved something, and perhaps in many years time we can talk about that. It was a good outcome for Australia, I might add. The only time you really came close to breaching my trust was the time you poached my senior advisor, Jono, who's probably still around there. He's up in the gallery.
Senator Cormann: A great man.

Senator PATRICK: He is a great man. The funny thing was that I knew that he was going to go to a better position from a career perspective, but I sent you a text, and it went something along the lines, 'Do you realise that Jono is the only one in my office that keeps me rational?' Very quickly, because he's always worried about relationships, he called me up and he said, 'Rex, I said to Jono that he couldn't come if you didn't approve.' Of course I approved, because it was a career advancement for Jono. But, again, that showed his sensitivity to the relationships. I know Jono has served you well, and, with some help with a letter to the Prime Minister, I'm happy to take him back!
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator PATRICK: Yes—well, the new crossbench. He's already upsetting me! We've always got on well, and I think there's a real friendship there.

I just want to go back to what I said, and I'd like to withdraw some of the harsh remarks that I made in that first question on notice, because actually, just recently, on clause 4.7, you did issue a guidance note which makes me much, much happier. So I think you've actually finally fulfilled everything you committed to. So I withdraw those remarks I made.

The OECD could do with a bloke like you. That's my advice. They could come off with much worse candidates than Mathias Cormann. As I said to you at the start, I'm sad to see you go, but can I just say: you'll never completely leave here because, as the transparency extremist that I am, I am going to, on a regular basis, use the 2009 Cormann motion. Others might not necessarily know what that means, but that is a fantastic motion, and I thank you for it. Mathias Cormann, good luck.

Senator REYNOLDS (Western Australia—Minister for Defence) (12:39): I too stand here to pay tribute to my colleague and friend Senator Mathias Cormann. Mathias, like myself, is a proud Western Australian and a very, very passionate Liberal, for all of the reasons he and others have articulated so wonderfully in the chamber here today. He is a great example of how good Australia is. He is also a great example, I think, of how good Liberals are.

Mathias, in speaking of your time in this place, many people have talked about the enormous contributions you've made as a senator, as a shadow minister and as a minister, but I would also like to share with some of the chamber the great contributions you made as a staffer prior to that.

Our nation does owe you, as has been articulated here, such a great thanks for the work that you have done, particularly in that relentless focus on trajectory during the seven last budgets. There is no time more than now when that has been so necessary.

I'd like to, as I said, take my opportunity to share a few reflections on Mathias in a little more of a personal sense. Mathias and I first got to know each other and work together in 2001 in the office of Senator Chris Ellison, where I was his chief of staff at the time. Chris was a wonderful mentor, as Mathias has said. We had a great office at the time. There was Mathias, Dean Smith, Christian Porter and many others. All of us do owe Chris a great debt of gratitude for that experience.

On reflection, I think there were a couple of things in that time that contributed to Mathias being the man and the minister he has been. That time in that office with Chris Ellison in 2001 and 2003, when I was there, shaped not only me but all of us in that office, going through the Bali bombings, September 11 and the issue with the boat arrivals and the deaths. We saw the best of humanity and we also saw the absolute worst of humanity. I know it shaped me in so many ways, as I'm sure it's contributed to making Mathias who he is, with his respect for human dignity and equality before the law and also in understanding the need in this job for great compassion and also great strength, particularly in national security.

Over the last 18 months, being on the National Security Committee of cabinet, I saw Mathias's very steady hand and wise guidance on that committee, dealing with significant issues of national security, COVID-19 and the bushfire season. Mathias, given the nature of those deliberations and noting there's only a small handful of us who would ever see it, your contribution to our nation's security cannot be underestimated.

There is something I want to share with you that has given me some insights into Mathias. Back in 2011 Chris Ellison brought the team together. I think Mathias came to see us as a second family. Over the last nearly 20 years, no matter how busy Mathias has been, he has done everything he can to keep that family together. Every year, no matter how busy, he brings all the past people who have worked for Chris Ellison together. As Mathias's family has grown, Chris Ellison's family has continued to be part of Mathias's family. There is no-one who barbecues Belgian sausages better than Mathias Cormann. There's also nobody who bakes a more impressive birthday cake than Mathias.

Again, Mathias, thank you for keeping that team together, and thank you for including us in your family's lives and giving us firsthand insight into some of the stressors and strains that Hayley and the girls have worn in your service. I say to our Defence families that their families serve alongside them in service of our nation, and your family has certainly served alongside you and made your contributions to our nation possible.

Like everybody else, I wish you all the best for the next phase of your career. I absolutely hope—I know you would make an outstanding Secretary-General to the OECD. I can tell you that the Ellison family would be more than happy to come to you for the next Christmas in Europe. In reference to cricket, I think you are possibly the finest Belgian batter and bowler that our nation has ever had. Good luck, and thank you for everything you've done for all of us.

Senator GALLAGHER (Australian Capital Territory—Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate) (12:44): I rise to add a contribution to the valedictory for Senator Cormann. I rise as shadow finance minister; I've only had that portfolio since May last year. I do have a critique of your performance as finance minister, but perhaps there's another time—this probably isn't the time!
Senator Cormann interjecting—

Senator GALLAGHER: Yes, I think that sounds pretty reasonable. On one of your most significant strengths, as many others have spoken about this morning: in politics a lot of people undervalue relationships, and it's been obvious to me, since I've come into the Senate, that that's something you've never done. You're able to build relationships across the chamber; I think the number of people in here and talking today shows how much people have valued that over time. I think that is underrated in politics. Politics at its heart is a very honourable profession—some of us are closer to that than others, perhaps! But serving the country, serving in the public way, is an honourable profession, and we need people who aspire to that and I think you have aspired to that in politics. Even though I disagree deeply with you on many aspects of politics itself, I do think that that's important and I think you've shown that it matters. As a leader, that matters because it permeates across the chamber. Senate relationships matter more than those in most chambers in minority parliaments. Without a leader that values them, this would be a much messier place than at other times.
I found you a rather frustrating opponent. When I try and put my finger on why, I think it is because you're very capable.
Senator Cormann: Sorry!

Senator GALLAGHER: A less capable opponent would have been more welcome! I went into estimates when I came to this place from government and came into opposition, and I thought I'd be really good at estimates. People use the cricket analogy—Senator Reynolds just did, and I think you might have as well. I would describe you as a handy all-rounder, really. At estimates I would try everything; I'd try to antagonise you, verbalise you, irritate you, go around you, go to the back of the budget books, go to the front of the budget books, just to find a way to penetrate what I saw as an immovable object in my way. But you've taught me a lot through that. You learnt from Penny and I've learned from you, so, when I'm finance minister, beware; I'm going to be fabulous! In terms of next estimates—and I said this to you before—please feel free to not attend. That's fine; leave approved!

On a personal note, I know that you and Penny have a very strong personal friendship; I saw a glimpse of that, working in the role I have. But I, too, have enjoyed some of the WhatsApp messages—the ambit, where they start and where we get to in the end. It would be an interesting trail if that confidence were ever to be betrayed—which it won't be! On a personal level, in my constitutional interlude, as I reflect on it, you were very kind to me—it was a difficult time—and I appreciate that very much.

In terms of the transition out, as someone who has left government and left being in the role where you make decisions and make things happen, it isn't as easy as you'd like to think. You think of all this quiet time and time with the family, which is all very lovely, but there's also a part of you that has to adjust to a role where you don't just pick up the phone and order a range of people to do certain things or where you're able to see a problem and fix it. I think Senator Keneally has experienced this; we all have, as we transition out of different roles. The caravan moves on very quickly. I think part of transitioning out is being kind to yourself and acknowledging that. Life is a funny thing. There are always other opportunities. I know life post politics will be very good for you. I hope that you get the time with your family that you need in the interim. I think the other thing capable people do is sign themselves up for so many things afterwards that they don't find that right balance.

I've enjoyed working with you, Mathias. I'm not going to miss you at estimates. I remember once moaning through estimates that we didn't get all your media releases and was there a reason why and some conspiracy why we were left off your email list. We'd tried to sign up. You assured me there was no issue and you'd go away and look at it and I've regretted it ever since because I get everything about four times! They really listen to you! They've signed me up and now I'm just, 'What has Mathias been up to?' Some days you're very busy. But all the best. I wish you and your family very well.

Senator RUSTON (South Australia—Minister for Families and Social Services and Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (12:51): How good is Mathias Cormann? The answer is, as I'm sure we all know, that he is very, very good. There are so many things we could stand here and bear testament to as to why he is so good, but I thought I'd share a couple of reasons why I think Mathias Cormann is so good. He has the most extraordinary skills at herding cats. As we know on our side, we have a very broad church and he has to keep all of us in the corral at the same time as he's trying to round up the crossbench. All the while he still seems to be able to keep a very close eye on what's going on on the other side of the chamber for any tactical moves that might bring his strategy of the day unstuck.

Another one of his great skills is that he is absolutely relentless, he is persistent and he has a committed work ethic. This guy doesn't ever leave anything in the tank, as we all know, and he will stay on the field until the absolute final siren, even when we're losing, with that tiny little hope that some miracle will occur and he will actually be able to win.

He is also extraordinarily generous. Mathias, I have been the recipient of your extraordinary generosity in terms of the time and the support that you have given to me. You've never ever shied away from spending time with me when I've had a problem, showing me the way forward. I thank you very much for the support that you've showed me. I believe that much of my success in my political career has been down to the fact that you backed me in and that you backed me in with those who made the decisions. So I thank you for where I am today.

So much has been said today in the chamber about Mathias, and I wish to associate myself with just about all of those comments—maybe not a few of the ones that we just got from Katy! You will certainly be missed in this place. I am certainly going to miss you. I am even going to miss the WhatsApp at all hours of the day and night! I absolutely and definitely am going to miss the Leeuwin Estate chardonnay! But I suppose the one thing that we all probably should miss is your ruthless honesty. I'm not sure, 'No, Anne,' is ever going to be delivered in quite the same way as yours was. Look, mate: good luck, my friend. The next chapter of your life is, I'm sure, going to be just as exciting as the last one. I hope it's at the OECD, but, wherever it is, they are going to be very lucky to have you. Go well.

Senator PRATT (Western Australia) (12:53): On behalf of WA Labor senators, I'd like to wish you, Senator Cormann, all the best for the future. When we first came into this place, your vigour and determination was evident from the outset. We did some community television together and Senator Cormann's dogged discipline around sticking to the key messages and key lines around the Gillard government's carbon tax was endemically successful, I'm very sad to say. It is a discipline that has clearly taken you to great heights in this place. I thank you for your service to the nation.

On marriage equality, the path that you took us on to get us there is not one with which I agreed, but I deeply respect your commitment to getting it resolved. It's terrific that those rights and privileges are now shared by all Australians and I thank you for your commitment to resolving that, notwithstanding the fact that a great many of us disagreed with the path that you took.
I'll miss seeing you down at O Day. Occasionally we'd bump into each other, you wearing a Liberal T-shirt and me wearing a 'Socialist Republic of Crawley' T-shirt kindly supplied by Labor students.

I'd also like to thank you for standing up for WA. The GST resolution is a significant milestone for our state. I thank you for working with the state Labor government and responding to the enormous pressure that the federal opposition put you under in order to get that resolved!
So, go well. I look forward to, I hope, seeing you active globally, but I'm sure I'll also be bumping into you at a polling booth in the near future.

Senator SESELJA (Australian Capital Territory—Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters) (12:56): It's good to associate myself with the very timely and generous remarks of many and to pay tribute to my good friend and colleague Mathias Cormann. Mathias and I met on a number of occasions before I was in this place. I remember meeting Mathias and Hayley and having a great night at a Young Liberals function, where we hit it off quite well, and I think that might have been one of our first meetings. But one of the meetings I remember most, before coming into this place, was around Christmas 2012, up here—Christmas party celebrations for the opposition, as it was then. I remember being sat down in Mathias's office, and he said to me: 'Zed, you should come join us here—it's very nice.' And I thought, 'Well, you know, there's something in that,' and I think it was Mathias's encouragement that was a very big part of my decision to come into this place. He did go on to say to me, 'You know, you're playing in the VFL; you should come play in the AFL!' And I'm glad that I did. I'm more of an NRL man myself, but I think, if we were to compare the Senate to the AFL, you'd have to acknowledge that, over the last few years, Mathias Cormann, for our team, has been our captain-coach and very much our best and fairest and has made an absolutely extraordinary contribution, and I think we can't overstate that contribution to the Senate, to our party and to our nation.

I've had the great privilege of being assistant finance minister to our greatest ever finance minister, and it's wonderful to be able to learn from the best—it really is. But can I say that, as much as I've been able to learn a lot from Mathias and his amazing office and the way he does things—and the Deputy Prime Minister and I of course exchange notes on what it's like to work as assistant finance minister—I've got to say: the other part about being assistant to Mathias is that it's really quite easy, because he absolutely does everything. He just makes sure he gets it all done, and he does that in the most professional way.

People have talked a lot about his energy and his commitment. I still remember that 30-plus-hour debate on Senate voting reform. The words 'Energizer Bunny' come to mind, in the way that Mathias stayed in there for the whole time—I think there were a couple of toilet breaks, but aside from that he was there—arguing the case, as the opposition were engaging in all sorts of games, and it was just a reflection of how much effort he puts in.

I want to have a couple of short reflections, briefly, before I finish, on Mathias as a thought leader for the Liberal Party—and, might I say, particularly for the conservatives within the Liberal Party as well. Mathias speaks passionately about seeing East and West Berlin and what that meant for his political philosophy—these ideas of freedom; these ideas of personal effort and reward for effort and stretching yourself. He speaks well, and he spoke very well in the speech again today. But I think also he has some other enduring values, about the importance of family, the importance of strong institutions and the value and worth and dignity of every human life. It is those things that I think have also made him a thought leader within our movement. Mathias, you've talked about being now 'Citizen' Cormann. Can I say—and I know many of my colleagues will appreciate this—that, to us, you are and will always be a very solid Citizen Cormann. We acknowledge that, and I want to acknowledge that on the record.

Can I say briefly that I think history will judge you very well. I think, in particular, you've had big moments where you've had to make big decisions, and you've been criticised for some of those decisions—I think, unfairly. I think history will judge the fact that you made the right decisions for our party and the right decisions for our nation, and I'd like the record to reflect that.

Just finally, I want to pay tribute to Hayley, and to Isabelle and Charlotte. Hayley is an amazing woman—an absolutely amazing woman. Of course, she has borne the burden that you have borne, but in a very different way and a very significant way. She has served our nation in being there for you and, as you point out, not just being an amazing wife and mother but going on to an extraordinary career of her own in the meantime. So I want to pay tribute to Hayley, and to Isabelle and Charlotte, and to thank her for lending you to our nation in this capacity for a number of years.
We wish you well. I look forward to seeing your future endeavours. Certainly, I believe Paris will not know what has hit it!

Senator COLBECK (Tasmania—Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians and Minister for Youth and Sport) (13:01): I too would like to make a short contribution to the valedictory for Senator Cormann—Mathias. I think it's important to associate myself with remarks across the chamber. It's Mathias's strength of character which is one of the things that's brought out the best in this place. There are not too many occasions where we all come together and we agree on something in the way that we have today, but, given Mathias's strength of character and his relationships across the chamber, this moment, where we all acknowledge the contribution that Mathias has made, is one of those moments that are the best of this place.

He made a point in his speech about philosophy—what he believed in and why. That has carried him all the way through his time here. I sincerely hope that, through the OECD, the rest of the world gets the opportunity to have the benefit of that. I really do wish you the very best in that quest, Mathias. Your philosophy and, in particular, your character—particularly your character—which has been demonstrated by the comments that have been made around the chamber today, will be of enormous benefit.

I can retire, I think, a newspaper clipping from the Mercury from 1981, where a former senator, Bob Brown, was extolling the virtue of building coal-fired power stations in the Fingal Valley when he was campaigning against renewable hydroelectricity in Tasmania. I think that can be retired back to my office, rather than being maintained here in the drawer in the chamber. I couldn't count the number of times I handed that to Mathias when he was responding to a question from our friends in the Greens.

The acknowledgement of his respect for this institution, I think, is a really important point, and I acknowledge the comments that Senator Wong made in that respect. This is an important chamber; it's an important institution, and it deserves the respect of all of us. It's very easy for us to get caught up in the hurly-burly of the contest across the chamber, but we all should remember what this institution is about and the importance of it. I acknowledge the comments that Senator Wong made with respect to the boundaries that we should all have in place in that sense. It's a really important sentiment and one we should remember. I too have felt the brunt of Senator Cormann at ERC, as so many on our side have, and the philosophy that he brings, but going in there when we're seeking resources—taxpayers' funds, taxpayers' resources—that we might want to expend is a really important discipline for us all. He always had a very strong and sound argument to back up his thoughts.

Senator Cormann has been an extraordinarily strong counsel for so many of us in this place. In the context of his leadership of the government in the Senate, he has been an extraordinarily strong shepherd in keeping the coalition working together and maintaining all of us where we needed to be—and, in the circumstances where some of us might not have been where we needed to be, making sure that we got there quickly. This is something senators would understand: I would regard Senator Cormann as a senator's senator. The fact that he's going out on estimates is probably the best demonstration of that. Senator Gallagher might like to see him go earlier, but we're very pleased—
Senator Gallagher interjecting—

Senator COLBECK: In a generous way—I'm happy to acknowledge that, Senator Gallagher! But the fact that Mathias is going out on estimates demonstrates that he is a senator's senator. People in this chamber understand that context, I think. He acknowledged the work that he did with now Prime Minister Morrison with respect to the GST. I know that my home state, Tasmania, played a very robust role in that. But the outcome that was achieved as part of that process, as you acknowledged in your valedictory speech, Mathias, is an important one; it was an important one for the country. I would like to acknowledge that.

As has been acknowledged across the chamber, he is a senator who gets things done, a minister who gets things done. We all have a time here. Mathias has acknowledged and understood his time, but using your time in this place effectively is a really important thing for us all to remember, because we all do have our time. He has done that and he has got things done, which is really important. His departure is going to be a huge loss to our side of politics—I think it will be a huge loss to the chamber—but I do hope that it will be a gain for the global finance organisation of the OECD. I really do wish him success in that.

As we all know, life is what happens to you while you're planning what you're going to do next. Whatever it is that happens next for you and your family, Mathias, I wish you all the very best. Thank you for your service to this chamber and to the country.

Senator DEAN SMITH (Western Australia—Government Whip in the Senate) (13:07): We have many privileges as senators, and one of those is to watch, at close proximity, events that shape the government, events that shape our country. Today is one of those events. It's an important day and a sad day. It's an important day for this Senate chamber, an important day for this coalition government and a very important day for Western Australia. We can't overstate just how significant this is. As someone who is very keen on the history of our parties and someone who is very keen on the history of this Senate chamber and our country, I suggest that there's been no more significant event in the life of this coalition government than the departure of our friend Mathias Cormann. We are all saddened by our loss but excited for Mathias and Hayley and the girls. It's not the end but the beginning of a bright, new and exciting chapter for Mathias, and we send him with our best wishes.

As we know, one of Mathias's greatest joys is when a plan comes together. Mathias and I have known each other a long time. I first met Mathias shortly after his arrival in Australia. Mathias and I have worked on some very big plans together, and they've been very visible. We've also worked on a few invisible plans. Again, it speaks to his character that Mathias's word is something that you can rely on; it is something that you can bank on.

We thank you very, very much for the way you have led this team. It's been a great honour, and I thank you very personally for the trust you've put in me to be the Chief Government Whip under your leadership. It's been a pleasure to do so.

Colleagues, we will be able to say, as others who come after today won't be able to say, that we worked with that senator, Senator Mathias Cormann—that we knew him; that he knew us. That is the greatest of privileges.

Senator DUNIAM (Tasmania—Assistant Minister for Forestry and Fisheries and Assistant Minister for Regional Tourism) (13:10): 'Great snakes!' is a phrase often used by Senator Cormann's animation hero, Tintin, and it is a phrase that came to mind—
Honourable senators interjecting—

Senator DUNIAM: Yes, Captain Haddock, in the movie! I've got a Captain Haddock one coming up. It was a phrase that came to mind when we learnt that Senator Cormann would be leaving us. Of course, the question that came to my mind was: 'Whatever will we do?' In reflecting on that question, I thought about the contribution that Senator Cormann has made as leader in this place and in several significant roles in the coalition over a long time, both in opposition and in government.

The biggest one, to me—I've been here a bit over four years now, but I'm still a relatively young member of our team—is the mentoring and the nurturing, and the shepherding, as I think Senator Colbeck referred to it, of the younger members of our team, bringing us in, helping us to understand how we can effectively advocate for our communities and advocate our beliefs in the party room, and, as Senator Dean Smith rightly said, find ways to bring plans together and actually get some good outcomes for the people we represent. Senator Cormann said in his remarks that he feels some comfort in leaving here because he leaves behind a great team, and I just want to say to Senator Cormann that I think there is good reason for that—because of the mentoring that he has done, the investment he has made in other members in this place, in the members of his team. It is an amazing legacy that this country will benefit from for generations to come.
Hopefully, I can get this Tintin quote right. As Red Rackham said to Sir Francis Haddock, 'We will meet again, in another time.' I wish you and your family well, and thank you—
Senator Cormann interjecting—
Senator DUNIAM: Two out of two ain't bad! But thank you, Senator Cormann.
Senator O'SULLIVAN (Western Australia) (13:12): Very well done!
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator Duniam: It was in French!

Senator O'SULLIVAN: I will keep my remarks brief. Mathias Cormann, I am here today because of your support. That is no exaggeration. You have mentored me. You guided me through the processes—through preselection, what it takes to serve the party, how to position myself. Now, as the newest Western Australian senator for the Liberal Party, I'm here very much because of your support and I'm very grateful for it.

You have a quality that some here have mentioned already, and I just want to echo that, and that is the quality of generosity. You have given so much to all of us, you have given so much to me, and the true mark of generosity is when you do that without an expectation of anything in return, and that's what you have shown. I just want to put on the record my sincere thanks to you, and to Hayley as well. Hayley has been an incredible encouragement to me in my journey to get here and since being here—supportive. She is an amazing woman and she is so encouraging. If you spend any time with Hayley, you leave feeling encouraged. And your family is beautiful. My wife and I look to you guys. We look at how you manage the busyness of life in this job but still maintain a very strong and beautiful relationship, and as a father to your children. Those of us in WA are a little closer and we get to see the impact that you have on your children and the beautiful way that you as a father, in spite of the pressures on you, provide that amazing support to them. I think it's a real testament to your quality and your character.

Can I also just say, for the Liberal Party in Western Australia, that the way you have helped, shepherded and provided leadership within the WA Liberal Party is phenomenal. You're going to be significantly missed in that. I hope we don't see you completely disappear in terms of—
Honourable senators interjecting—

Senator O'SULLIVAN: Not leaving the party—that's good! Mathias, we're a very strong division, and it's a tribute to you. There are many others who have contributed to that, but I think it would be hard to find anyone who has had such an impact upon the WA Liberal Party. On behalf of other Liberal Party members, including those who are back home—we've got a state election coming up—I say there are so many candidates who I think would all love to be able to stand here like this today and just say thank you for what you've done. The great organisation that we have back there is very much a tribute to you, and I thank you very much indeed.

Senator BROCKMAN (Western Australia—Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (13:16): [by video link] It's truly an honour to be able to make a contribution on the departure of my good friend and, up until now, seemingly perennial boss, Mathias Cormann—7½ years as a staffer and three years in the Senate with Mathias as Senate leader. What can I say but, 'Free at last, free at last!'?

When I first went to work for Mathias, I was only going to be there for a year or two but the things we all know about Mathias—the fine mind, the extraordinary work ethic and the ability to understand both the policy and the politics of an issue—kept me there and, in the end, helped bring me into the Senate. Opposition was tough, but Mathias absolutely made the most of it, with forensic use of orders for the production of documents, the changes to the public interest immunity claims which Senator Patrick spoke about, and a number of committee reports that changed the public debate on issues. This demonstration and proved level of achievement improved our public life and improved the Senate.

In my time as Mathias's senior staffer, I'd often get the question, with raised eyebrows, 'What's he like to work for?' I'd never say it was the easiest of jobs, but it was extraordinarily rewarding. Mathias's attention to detail was and is legendary, beyond the level of mere mortals such as myself. The standards he set for himself were incredibly demanding. The middle-of-the-night Sky News slots—Western Australian time, that is—are legendary. Less well known are the draft committee reports, hundred of pages long, that were his holiday reading. But Mathias was also very conscious of the impact of the life we led on family and was always unhesitating in being as flexible as possible to make the demands, at least on his staff, more manageable. I'm not sure you always allowed yourself that leeway, Mathias, but certainly, from a staffing point of view, you were extraordinarily generous.

I will add my thanks and acknowledgment to Mathias's staff, many of whom I worked with—in particular Natasha Lobo, who's been there from the beginning, but also exceptional people like Philippa Campbell, Daniel Clode, Chris Browne, Karen Wu and so many others. The fact that Mathias attracted and retained such exceptional people says a lot about Mathias as a boss but also Mathias as a man.

Mathias is trustworthy and honourable. He has been in a position where he's had to take the hard decisions, and the thing that I most admire about you, Mathias, is that you have never shirked that responsibility. You're not one to dwell on the past, but history will record that bravery well. The accolades Mathias receives as Australia's longest-serving finance minister and, in my possibly biased opinion, the finest and, without doubt, the most influential finance minister are well earned. As Mathias has said many times, no-one is indispensable to the team, but, Mathias, you will be sorely missed. You have been a loyal boss, a good friend and a very supportive colleague. You are a wonderful servant to the conservative cause, to our great Liberal Party, to Western Australia and to our nation.

I described in my first speech how Mathias's advice led me to meeting Rebecca, so I won't repeat that today. Suffice it to say that your ongoing advice will be always highly valued by me and by so many of our colleagues. From Rebecca and my family to you, Hayley, Isabelle and Charlotte: all the best for whatever the future holds.

Senator KITCHING (Victoria) (13:20): [by video link] I'd like to add my voice to the valedictory speeches for Senator Cormann. I first spoke with Senator Cormann at estimates, and after a Remembrance Day event in Canberra in 2017, where Senator Cormann spoke movingly about the consequences of the First World War for his country of birth, Belgium. It was obvious to anyone who heard that speech the understanding Senator Cormann has of the human condition. But it was really after a tweet of mine—a rather inflammatory tweet, I hasten to add—when Senator Cormann phoned to ask if he could speak with me about it. I have to say it is not often my experience, Mr President, that my Twitter leads to the making of a new friend! Often have we met to have a glass of Western Australian wine or two, and/or champagne, and occasionally some corn chips as well. But this is the measure of Senator Cormann.

Not only in recent days, when people have said deservedly kind things, but even since before I came to this place, I have heard senators from all sides, and also members of the Liberal Party, say good things about Senator Cormann. He is someone who deals with people as he finds them, someone who is generous with people. He is someone who has the characteristics of both that other famous Belgian, Tintin—his morality and authenticity—and Asterix the Gaul, who is renowned for his shrewd intelligence and his bravery. I know Senator Cormann is very familiar with both these characters. Similarly, we both read Asterix in Latin as part of the fun part of studying that language at school. I know that recently Senator Cormann's office purchased some Tintin-themed masks!

Could I turn to Senator Cormann's office. Wise people in this building have told me that parliamentarians' offices often reflect the parliamentarian. Senator Cormann's staff members are professional, happy and always gracious to odd visitors to their office, and I thank them for that and for always making me feel welcome.

We know from his own valedictory speech a short time ago the regard that Senator Cormann has for history and philosophy and for the greatness of democracy. We know that in this place it is not the people vibrant with passion for how Australia can be a better place who are unwanted but, rather, those who cease to care. The people in this place who are engaged, who do care, who are willing to have the argument both in the chamber and outside but to do so with respect, who can find common ground—for all of those people—Senator Cormann is an exemplar, and his kindness and his compassion for his fellow human beings is at the forefront.

Senator Cormann, Australia has been very lucky to have you in this place, and your family have been very generous in that regard. And the OECD would be very lucky to have you as the Secretary-General. Wherever life takes you, you will always have your excellent character and your sense of humour. So it's not 'adieu' but, rather, 'bonne chance pour la suite et a bientot!'

The PRESIDENT (13:23): I will take the opportunity to briefly conclude the debate. I promise to be brief. I will not repeat everything everyone has said but will tell a few anecdotes that illustrate the points that everyone has made, the common themes mentioned here today. Personally, I think we should all acknowledge, particularly those of us from the east, that the burden carried by people coming from the west, and by their families, to play an active role in public life in Australia is truly extraordinary. When you combine that with the work ethic of Mathias, which others have spoken about, the burden not only upon him but also on Hayley and the girls and those others close to him has been extraordinary. It is so much tougher because of the time differences and the sheer number of hours on planes.

Mathias's work ethic was demonstrated in many ways, but in my case, when I was ill, he had to step into my portfolio. All I remember is my staff telling me when I came back to work that it was fantastic because, at 11 o'clock on a Thursday night, when he got off the plane in Perth, their phones weren't lighting up with all the WhatsApp messages and emails that had been prepared on the plane on the way over, because every single minute was a minute to take advantage of for his purpose in public life.

When I sat on ERC for a couple of years, Mathias's command of detail—without meaning to begrudge anyone else—was truly extraordinary. The size of those folders and the breadth of government activity was very difficult for any person to get across, but Mathias did. I do think I hold the record as the only spending minister to come into ERC and, when having a program cut, offer up more and say, 'You can have the whole program.' It was the only time I think I saw Mathias's stone visage at ERC crack, because he hadn't had that happen before.

Without meaning to be flippant—someone else might have claimed the title—Mathias was the fixer of the government. The fixing of the government actually has to happen in this chamber. This is where announcements in the other place, down at the other end of this building, get turned into law and public resources get determined, whether they're tax cuts or spending programs. If you can't make this chamber work you can't make the Australian parliament work, and everyone has an experience of that. Mathias would happily prosecute a collective decision, and he did not take differences personally. I had my share of differences—life would be boring if we didn't—on our own side and on the other side, but Mathias always had the ability to go on with the collective decision that was taken with a common purpose. In the end, I would say that he held himself to the standards he expected of others, and that is really one thing we can all aspire to and share.

Mathias: congratulations. To your family: very best wishes. To you professionally: very best wishes. Farewell for the last time from the chamber, if not from the work of the Senate over the next few weeks.
Pursuant to order, the Senate will now adjourn without debate. I remind senators that legislation committees will meet to consider estimates, commencing on Monday 19 October at 9 am.
